text: And that force is a scope. Okay, so as we grow in our product career, our scope grows, and we kind of like that, which is all great, but at some point, if you haven't already gotten there, many of you have, but for those of you who haven't, you will get there, where your scope will be so large, that no matter what you do in terms of efficiency, whatever framework you use for prioritization, whatever framework or tool you use to manage your to-do list, whatever tools and techniques you use, whatever prioritization you do, your scope is so large that you are still going to be incredibly busy.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny asks Shreyas about his first question, which is 'Why am I so busy?' Shreyas explains that he spent most of his career feeling extremely stressed and busy despite working hard. He discusses how productivity tips and time management techniques can help initially, but eventually hit a wall. Shreyas identifies scope expansion as the core issue - as you advance in your career, your responsibilities grow to a point where no amount of efficiency improvements can keep up.
vocabulary_highlights: no matter what you do in terms of efficiency
text_ko: 그 힘은 바로 스코프(scope)예요. 프로덕트 경력(product career)이 쌓일수록 담당 스코프가 넓어지고, 우리도 그걸 좋아해요. 그런데 어느 순간(이미 도달하신 분들도 많겠지만 아직 아닌 분들도 있을 거예요), 스코프가 너무 커져서 아무리 효율성(efficiency)을 높이고, 어떤 우선순위(prioritization) 프레임워크(framework)를 쓰고, 어떤 할 일 목록(to-do list) 관리 도구나 기법을 써도 결국 엄청 바쁠 수밖에 없어요.
text_zh: 而这个力量就是范围。好吧，随着我们在产品生涯中不断成长，我们的工作范围也在扩大，我们也挺喜欢这样的，这都挺好的，但是到了某个节点——如果你还没到那个程度的话，你们很多人已经经历过了，但对于那些还没经历过的人来说，你们迟早会遇到——你的工作范围会变得非常大，无论你在效率方面做什么努力，无论你用什么框架来排优先级，无论你用什么框架或工具来管理你的待办事项(to-do list)，无论你用什么工具和技巧，无论你怎么排优先级，你的工作范围就是这么大，你还是会忙得不可开交。
text_es: Y esa fuerza es el alcance. Bueno, entonces conforme vamos creciendo en nuestra carrera de producto, nuestro alcance crece, y como que nos gusta eso, lo cual está genial, pero en algún momento, si no han llegado ya ahí, muchos de ustedes ya llegaron, pero para los que no, van a llegar, donde su alcance va a ser tan grande, que no importa lo que hagan en términos de eficiencia, cualquier metodología que usen para priorizar, cualquier metodología o herramienta que usen para manejar su lista de pendientes, cualesquiera herramientas y técnicas que usen, cualquier priorización que hagan, su alcance es tan grande que de todas formas van a estar increíblemente ocupados.
key_sentence: Your scope grows, but efficiency won't reduce your incredible busyness.

text: And so what I realized, Lenny, is you don't have to go through these four to six weeks, and it was an accident. Basically, what happened is around that time, the product I was working on, Stripe Connect, it's like a major product for Stripe, major, major business for Stripe. And I had put together a product strategy, like a real product strategy for this product.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny asks about Shreyas' experience with annual planning cycles that typically consume 4-6 weeks. Shreyas describes how most teams go through elaborate planning rituals, create detailed plans, but then abandon them within weeks due to customer escalations and changing priorities. He explains how having a genuine product strategy (not a superficial one) allowed him to complete his planning for a major Stripe product in just three days instead of the usual lengthy process.
text_ko: 그래서 제가 깨달은 건, 레니, 꼭 4~6주를 거칠 필요는 없다는 거였어요. 그리고 그건 우연히 그렇게 된 일이었어요. 사실 그때 제가 맡고 있던 제품인 스트라이프 커넥트(Stripe Connect)는 스트라이프에게 정말 큰 제품이자 핵심 사업이었고, 저는 그 제품을 위해 진짜 제품 전략(product strategy)을 세웠어요.
text_zh: 所以我发现，Lenny，其实你不用非得花那四到六周的时间，这完全是个意外发现。基本上是这样的，当时我在做的那个产品 Stripe Connect，这可是 Stripe 的核心产品，对 Stripe 来说是超级重要的业务。然后我为这个产品制定了一个产品策略，就是那种真正的产品策略。
text_es: Y entonces lo que me di cuenta, Lenny, es que no tienes que pasar por esas cuatro a seis semanas, y fue de casualidad. Básicamente, lo que pasó es que por esa época, el producto en el que estaba trabajando, Stripe Connect, es como un producto súper importante para Stripe, un negocio súper, súper importante para Stripe. Y había armado una estrategia de producto, o sea, una estrategia de producto de verdad para este producto.
key_sentence: It was an accident that led to a real product strategy for Stripe Connect.

text: The challenge here with this kind of approach, and again, this is what happens in practice, I'm not talking about whatever theory you read, this is what happens in practice. So when you follow this approach and you assume that, 'Oh, this is a two-way door, we can kill the feature,' in reality, it doesn't work out that way, because here's what happens in reality.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny and Shreyas are discussing why product managers stay so busy. Shreyas explains that one major reason is making poor product decisions, often justified by concepts like 'two-way doors' (reversible decisions). He argues that while these decisions seem reversible in theory, in practice they become one-way commitments. Teams make quick feature decisions without properly thinking through customer motivation, differentiation, or distribution strategy, assuming they can easily reverse course later.
vocabulary_highlights: it doesn't work out that way
text_ko: 문제는 이런 방식인데, 다시 말하지만 이건 읽은 이론 얘기가 아니라 실제로 현장에서 일어나는 일이에요. 그래서 이 접근을 따르면서 ‘이건 되돌릴 수 있는 결정(two-way door)이니까 기능을 지워도 괜찮다’고 가정하면, 현실은 그렇게 안 돌아가요. 실제로는 이런 일이 벌어지거든요.
text_zh: 这种做法的问题在于，我再强调一遍，这是实际操作中会遇到的情况，我说的不是你在书上看到的那些理论，而是真正干活时碰到的事儿。所以当你采用这种方法，心想"没事，这是个可逆决策(two-way door)，大不了砍掉这个功能"，但现实中根本不是这么回事，因为实际情况是这样的。
text_es: El problema con este tipo de enfoque, y otra vez, esto es lo que pasa en la práctica, no estoy hablando de cualquier teoría que hayas leído, esto es lo que pasa en la práctica. Entonces cuando sigues este enfoque y asumes que, 'Ah, esta es una puerta de doble vía, podemos matar la funcionalidad,' en realidad, no funciona así, porque esto es lo que pasa en realidad.
key_sentence: This kind of approach assumes a two-way door, but it doesn't work out that way.

text: We use data when it favors us, we use anecdotes when it favors us. So anyway, so we present that. Now we do have the sales counterpart in the room too, our sales counterpart, and they say, 'You know what, though? We are still not winning many deals because of this feature.' And so of course the CEO asks, 'So what's up? Why aren't we winning deals, even though we have the feature?'
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Shreyas is explaining why product decisions that seem reversible ('two-way doors') actually trap teams in more work. He describes a common scenario where a feature launches with poor adoption, but during quarterly business reviews, product managers use favorable anecdotes to make it sound successful. However, when sales teams point out the feature isn't helping win deals, it forces the product team to commit to building additional features to make it 'table stakes' competitive.
text_ko: 우리는 유리할 때는 데이터(data)를 쓰고, 유리할 때는 일화(anecdotes)를 들곤 해요. 어쨌든 그렇게 제시해요. 그리고 여기 우리 영업 담당자(sales counterpart)도 있는데, 그쪽은 "사실 이 기능(feature) 때문에 아직도 많은 계약(deals)을 못 따고 있어요"라고 말해요. 그러면 당연히 CEO는 "무슨 일이에요? 기능이 있는데도 왜 계약을 못 따는 거예요?"라고 물어봐요.
text_zh: 我们有利的数据就拿数据说话，有利的案例就拿案例说事儿。反正就是这么汇报的。不过销售那边的同事也在场，他们就说："话虽如此，但是我们因为这个功能成交的单子还是不多。" CEO当然就问了："怎么回事？我们明明有这个功能，为什么还是拿不下单子？"
text_es: Usamos los datos cuando nos convienen, usamos las anécdotas cuando nos convienen. Bueno, el caso es que presentamos eso. Ahora, también tenemos al equipo de ventas ahí en la sala, y nos dicen: "Mira, la cosa es que todavía no estamos cerrando muchos negocios por esta funcionalidad." Y claro, el CEO pregunta: "¿Y qué pasa? ¿Por qué no estamos cerrando deals aunque tengamos la funcionalidad?"
key_sentence: We use data when it favors us, but still struggle with winning many deals.

text: But what we need to understand is it's game recognize game before the game is called, right? Like, game recognize game in the practice session. Because it takes no genius right now to say, 'Well, Patrick Mahomes is great quarterback,' or, 'Virat Kohli is a great cricketer,' or whatever else. It requires no genius to do that. It requires zero taste.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny asks about Shreyas' second question: 'Do I actually have good taste?' Shreyas explains that taste isn't just about product design, but about the ability to identify what is truly good before its results are obvious. He uses the sports phrase 'game recognize game' to illustrate that real taste means recognizing excellence early, not after someone becomes obviously successful. He argues that calling Jensen Huang a genius in 2024 requires no taste since NVIDIA's success is evident, but recognizing his potential in 2010 would have demonstrated real insight.
text_ko: 근데 우리가 이해해야 할 건, 경기가 시작되기 전에 이미 실력 있는 사람은 서로 알아본다는 거예요(game recognize game). 연습 세션에서부터 바로 드러나거든요. 지금 '패트릭 마홈스가 훌륭한 쿼터백이다'거나 '비랏 콜리가 훌륭한 크리켓 선수다'라고 말하는 데는 천재일 필요 없어요. 전혀 안목이나 특별한 감각이 필요한 얘기가 아니에요.
text_zh: 但是我们要明白的是，真正的高手在比赛开始之前就能相互认出对方，对吧？就是说，在练习的时候高手就能识别高手。因为现在谁都能说"帕特里克·马霍姆斯是个好四分卫"或者"维拉特·科利是个好板球手"什么的，这根本不需要什么眼光。完全不需要什么品味。
text_es: Pero lo que tenemos que entender es que hay que reconocer el talento antes de que se haga famoso, ¿no? O sea, hay que identificar a los buenos cuando todavía están en las prácticas. Porque ahora mismo cualquiera puede decir "Ay, Patrick Mahomes es un quarterbackazo" o "Virat Kohli es un crack del cricket" o lo que sea. Para eso no hace falta ser un genio. Eso no requiere ningún ojo clínico.
key_sentence: Game recognize game before the game is called; it requires zero taste.

text: So I see this in everything. Like, let's see, the other one is we also get very impressed with complicated charts and math we don't understand. And some of you product leaders who are at the top of the game, you actually use this as a strategy.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Shreyas continues discussing the question 'Do I actually have good taste?' He's explaining how product leaders often get swayed by superficial factors rather than substance. He points out that people are attracted to catchy metaphors (like 'two-way doors' vs 'reversible decisions') and alliterations (like 'fail fast' vs 'fail quickly') rather than evaluating ideas on merit. He suggests that some senior product leaders deliberately use complicated presentations to appear more authoritative, exploiting these psychological biases.
vocabulary_highlights: at the top of the game
text_ko: 저는 이걸 모든 곳에서 봐요. 예를 들면, 또 하나는 우리가 이해하지 못하는 복잡한 차트나 수학에 너무 쉽게 감탄한다는 거예요. 그리고 업계 최고 수준의 프로덕트 리더(product leaders)들 중에는 이걸 전략으로 일부러 쓰는 분들도 있어요.
text_zh: 所以我发现这种情况到处都是。比如说，另外一个就是我们特别容易被那些复杂的图表和看不懂的数学搞得一愣一愣的。你们当中一些顶尖的产品负责人，其实就是把这个当策略在用。
text_es: Entonces esto lo veo en todo. O sea, mira, otra cosa es que también nos impresionamos mucho con gráficos complicados y matemáticas que no entendemos. Y algunos de ustedes que son líderes de producto que están en la cima, en realidad usan esto como estrategia.
key_sentence: We get very impressed with complicated charts, but top leaders use this as a strategy.

text: So when I realized this, I said, when a team grew to a certain size, so when I was at Stripe and I realized this, when the team I was managing, it had a fan out of about 50 people, so this includes engineers and everything, I said, 'This is enough.' Because for me, any time a team goes to like 50s, and 100s, and beyond, it is a law of corporations that you're going to have to spend a lot of time at the optics level.
speaker: Shreyas Doshi
context: Lenny asks about Shreyas' third question: 'Why does my job feel so frustrating?' Shreyas explains that frustration comes from operating misaligned with your superpowers. He describes three levels of product work: impact, execution, and optics. While his happy place was the impact level, corporate growth forced him to spend more time on optics (managing up, presentations, politics). At Stripe, he deliberately capped his team size at 50 people to avoid spending most of his time on optics work, choosing alignment with his strengths over traditional career advancement.
text_ko: 그래서 이걸 깨달았을 때 저는 이렇게 생각했어요. 팀이 어느 정도 규모로 커지면—스트라이프에 있을 때 제가 맡고 있던 팀의 팬아웃(fan-out)이 엔지니어 포함해서 대략 50명이었는데—'이 정도면 충분하다'고요. 제 경험상 팀이 50명대, 100명대, 그 이상으로 가면 회사의 불문율처럼 '옵틱스 수준(optics level)'에 많은 시간을 써야 해요.
text_zh: 所以当我意识到这一点的时候，我就想，当一个团队发展到一定规模的时候——那时候我在Stripe，我意识到这个问题——当我管理的团队，包括工程师什么的，总共有50个人左右的时候，我就说："够了。" 因为对我来说，任何时候团队规模到了50人、100人或者更多，按照公司的规律，你就必须花大量时间在表面功夫上。
text_es: Entonces cuando me di cuenta de esto, dije, cuando un equipo creció hasta cierto tamaño, o sea cuando estaba en Stripe y me di cuenta de esto, cuando el equipo que yo manejaba tenía como unas 50 personas bajo mi responsabilidad, incluyendo ingenieros y todo, dije: "Ya es suficiente." Porque para mí, cada vez que un equipo llega a los 50, y después a los 100 y más allá, es una ley de las corporaciones que vas a tener que pasar muchísimo tiempo ocupándote de las apariencias.
key_sentence: A team fan out of about 50 people means focusing on the optics level.
